title: Wednesday, 27th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
Deep Breath everyone... Afternoon
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Hey. Hello. Welcome. Hi. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

Grouchmonkey Kalimera
Soundbuy Morning all........
Manxish Morning
BE11:10am

Fair amount to get through today, starting here.

BE11:10am

Soundbuy Who him..........?
Deep Breath everyone... Duncan Goodhew!
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Ian Griffiths, soon to be ex of ITV

Grouchmonkey Duncan Goodhew? Telly Savalas? I give up
Soundbuy Stressful job obviously.......
Upaswellasdown Morning all. Ian's a nice guy
Deep Breath everyone... He was like a rug before
Mr Diamond why can't he look at the camera
Soundbuy He's admiring his options.....
Upaswellasdown but not sure he can take credit for 'transforming' ITV. Last I looked, it was still heavily reliant on advertising, and remains very operationally geared
Mr Diamond Has the Dame pushed him
BE11:14am

(@ROTR: let he who doesn't feel the creep of male pattern baldness throw the first stone.)

Deep Breath everyone... @BE - that is not a pattern
BE11:15am

Ten years at ITV, of course. And of course his departure is five months after the arrival of Dame Carolyn Julia McCall, DBE.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

So ... what's happened here? He's sticking around for a year to sort out an orderly changeover, suggesting it's not too dirty.

Deep Breath everyone... Not saying he looks like an egg, but has he been poached by someone else?
BE11:16am

.... Was it simply a case that he was overlooked for the top job .....

pancakes or waffles well player sir/m'am
pancakes or waffles *played, even
Soundbuy There's nothing like a Dame.......apparently.........
BE11:17am

.... in favour of someone who spent £50m on some printing presses in 2005 that needed to be thrown out little more than a decade later.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

( https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-06-12/ )

casapinos https://www.ft.com/content/43a054c8-7626-11e8-b326-75a27d27ea5fhttps://www.ft.com/content/43a054c8-7626-11e8-b326-75a27d27ea5fMight be useful reading for mr griffiths?
BE11:18am

..... Or does it signal something more drastic at ITV?

BE11:18am

Dame C has a strategy rejig due quite soon.

Upaswellasdown She must be good at something, given her career trajectory
11:19 am
BE11:19am

It might be that Mr Griffiths -- who, to remind, rebuilt ITV from when it was a debt-hole trading at 16p in 2009 -- doesn't like what's coming?

Stateless IMO very, very negative for ITV
BE11:20am

Mr Griffiths has historically liked cash generation, solid debt ratings, dividends, stuff like that.

BE11:20am

Ms McCall, not so much.

chad_john Beat up ITV just as it was on the up. Cheers. I hold, obvs.
Soundbuy Hopefully nothing do do with the stellar Ent One performance of late....
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Here's Citi, who reckon there are lots of reasons to be fearful.

BE11:21am

The question for many investors is likely to be whether there are any obvious changes in direction that Mr Griffiths’ departure might signal. With this in mind, Mr Griffiths had been fairly clear in his view of several things over time. He has always been very clear that ITV needs to maintain control of ad sales and, perhaps not unsurprisingly given his experience, he has also been a strong advocate for the group maintaining a strong balance sheet. We believe the market could interpret this news as a sign that the strategic refresh may be more transformational than initially suggested and could involve more investment (either opex related or deal related). We have also seen evidence that Carolyn McCall is prepared to be pragmatic about collaboration with others in the broadcaster industry, so it could pave the way for a closer allegiance with others as a means to position itself for changing consumers viewing habits.

BE11:22am

"closer allegiance with others"?

11:23 am
BE11:23am

There are plenty of US companies desperate for stuff right now. Amazon, for one.

BE11:23am

Interesting thing from MoffettNathanson yesterday saying Amazon needs to fix Prime Video, and buying a media company would be the easy way.

BornCynic @Upaswellasdown - heard her talk at Canterbury University - where she studied - very confident. Which I think is the main qualification required?
Soundbuy ITV studios/production arm often overlooked..........
BE11:24am

They mention CBS as a plausible target. But what about Amazon JV-ing ITV Studios?

BornCynic Amazon finally hooked me into that free Prime trial - I clicked too quickly. So now an suffering "The Grand Tour" and ordering everything for next day delivery as an act of revenge on the Amazon marketing department.
11:25 am
BE11:26am

Global, translatable formats, such as that dumb Love Island thing that's always on. Bit of heritage Upstairs Downstairs stuff in there too.

chad_john Plus Football, BE.
BE11:26am

I suggest this entirely speculatively, to be clear. But stranger things have happened.

BE11:26am

(On Netflix.)

BornCynic Prime consists mainly of tat that I would only watch if Amazon paid me - not the other way round.
Upaswellasdown @Soundbuy, I think the value of studios is not as great as ITV say, sure it's a bigger part of their business than it was but remarkably volatile and still reliant on a few hits for its external revenue
chad_john that's any content industry in a nutshell though.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

What you'd get, of course, is that ITV would be a bit like AstraZeneca. Reliant on externalisation revenue so not fully benefiting from pipeline.

Grouchmonkey Bought ITV about a month ago, because I bought the idea it had lots of good stuff other media companies would want. However, the bottom line is that none of them have moved on it, so I just sold out. which means, of course......
Upaswellasdown ITV's treasurer back in 2009 deserves much of the credit for avoiding a rights issue. Some very funky debt financings in 2008-2010
BE11:28am

Though perhaps it's wrong to talk about Ant and Dec's Saturday Takeaway as a equivalent to immunotherapy. Back to Citi.

BE11:28am

Looking at the implications of this, the signaling is not ideal. Best case,
the group is losing a talented executive with real knowledge and understanding of the business based on over a decade of experience; worst case it could signal a more dramatic change in approach to strategic the reinvention of the group. We are more inclined to the former – that this is a natural evolution – but, either way, in the very near term, we believe the market will be cautious about this news.

MonkeyTrader The IWG profit warning today was quite entertaining. Tosca got on the call today to question the timing. Any thoughts out there as to why IWG have decided to pull forward costs during a bid period???
11:29 am
BE11:29am

And Liberum, which gave everyone a scare at 8am by titling its email "CEO / COO to step down".

Excel Developer Hey hey its the monkeys
Soundbuy @Upaswellasdown - still. plenty willing to pay up for such, Ent One acquired the Mark Gordon Co. on such a basis.......
BE11:29am

That hasn't happened, to be clear.

BE11:30am

an was one of the key drivers of the strategy that turned ITV from the dark days of 2008/9 and was fundamental in improving the company’s financial position. He leaves ITV in very good health, not just from a financial perspective but also from an operational one. ITV1’s audience share is up 9.2% yoy YTD to June 17th (17.1% vs. 15.6% for 2017) and the growth of Online Video on Demand advertising is accelerating ITV’s total advertising growth, with Q1 total advertising at +3% vs +1% for ITV TV advertising alone. The success of “Love Island” on ITV2, which saw its first week with an average audience at 3.8m including time delayed viewing vs. 2.2m in 2017, and with a 51% share of the very attractive 18-24 demographic, should also help boost ITV’s performance.

ITV gives its 1H trading update on July 25th. It has guided to “broadly” flat TV advertising growth for Q1 and +2% for total advertising (including VOD). However, we think there could be some upside risk to that, in particular June’s +17% TV growth guidance given the success of the World Cup and the return of “Love Island”.

11:30 am
undefined
BE11:31am

And since we're doing acronyms, IWG

IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 312.10, down 12.1 (-3.73%), High: 315.90, Low: 301.10, Volume: 3.28m

11:37 am

It's always been the case that, if Mark Dixon is selling -- and it's been clear for quite a while that he's interested in selling -- you need to be pretty damn confident to take the other side of the deal.

Dec69 - Skeptic I'm thinking of putting together a glorified REIT/Rental Business, where my A* tenants who are a success move on normally in 14 months, my late payers and higher risk tenants stay. What could go wrong?
BE11:38am

Not sure a £30 pull forward of capex and a warning that the UK is tricky has really changed that.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, there's some real stupid money around at the moment. So you never know who may end up bidding.
A. M. Morning all. This being almost the silly season, here's something fun:"An extended flow test is set to begin at the Horse Hill oil discovery in the UK’s onshore Wealand basin in PEDL 137.Horse Hill partner Solo Oil confirmed Wednesday flow testing operations had commenced on the HH-1 well, with all key equipment on site to carry out the 150-day long-term extended flow test campaign. " (source: UPSTREAM).will there be crowds watching the flow?

Anyway, we wait for some kind of resolution to the auction. While on the subject though .....

11:39 am

Want something on WeWork?

BE11:40am

Here's BMO Capital Markets, which ....

BE11:40am

We attended a standing-room-only presentation by WeWork at its global
HQ in New York, in which it presented to business leaders its momentous impact on real estate. The message, in our view, is that WeWork has created significant value, and is "open for business" with office owners for increased partnerships to share in this value creation – striving to have its cake and eat it too. We believe this relationship is currently symbiotic but increasingly poses a competitive threat to office owners.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

$35bn valuation, tho.

Pharma @Dec69, I think it needs tranches to really make it a success. You can sell the high yield ones to German & French banks.
BE11:41am

The company has already made strides in real estate with the formation of WeWork Property Investors with JV partner Rhone Group, recently raising approximately $400mm to invest in real estate it occupies. The JV made headlines by acquiring Lord & Taylor's flagship store at 424 Fifth Ave. for $850mm, subleasing the bottom 150k sf back to the department store. This is the fifth largest transaction in NYC over the past 12 months

Tom Dalgleish Wasnt Wework exposed for dodgy accounting in FT a while ago?
BE11:42am

WeWork hosted a panel that included its landlords Boston Properties (BXP), Columbia Property (CXP) and Silverstein Properties. The panel was generally in agreement that co-working is an operating model that taps an under-served market - and the owners have no interest to enter this membership business. BXP's EVP John Powers could see co-working being 2-5% of the office market, but probably not 10% (not including enterprise leasing).

Tom Dalgleish Like counting something twice?
Dec69 - Skeptic You made me snort my coffee @Pharma
11:42 am
BE11:43am

...but Enterprise leasing poses a threat. However, enterprise leasing is a part of WeWork's business that landlords view as addressable competition. Silverstein offers Silver Suites – flexible, turnkey office space for growing companies; and CXP stated it may offer a similar concept in one of its Chelsea buildings. We believe landlords may need to offer more of this space to capture demand, which may alter the current risk/reward dynamic. Alternatively, they may invest in a WeWork competitor, as we suggested in 2018 REIT Predictions.

BE11:45am

This Pinnacle/Conagra deal's on the tape.

BE11:46am

CHICAGO and PARSIPPANY, N.J., June 27, 2018 PRNewswire -- Conagra Brands, Inc. (NYSE: CAG) and Pinnacle Foods Inc. (NYSE: PF) today announced that their boards of directors have unanimously approved a definitive agreement under which Conagra Brands will acquire all outstanding shares of Pinnacle Foods in a cash and stock transaction valued at approximately $10.9 billion, including Pinnacle Foods' outstanding net debt. Under the terms of the transaction, Pinnacle Foods shareholders will receive $43.11 per share in cash and 0.6494 shares of Conagra Brands common stock for each share of Pinnacle Foods held. The implied price of $68.00 per Pinnacle Foods share is based on the volume-weighted average price of Conagra Brands' stock for the five days ended June 21, 2018. The purchase price reflects an adjusted EBITDA multiple of 15.8x, based on Pinnacle Foods' estimated fiscal year 2018 results excluding synergies, and 12.1x adjusted EBITDA including run-rate cost synergies.

BE12:00pm

We have long thought that a merger of Sainsbury and ASDA makes sense – the question is whether the competition remedies will render the proposed deal uneconomic. The view of the CMA will likely remain unknown until mid-2019. We are skeptical about store disposals being highly material given that both companies have taken extensive advice and are investing considerable credibility into the transaction. Having had more time to run the numbers and explore alternative scenarios, we upgrade our stock rating to Overweight. We believe Sainsbury is worth 400p per share on a merged basis and 285p on a standalone basis – assuming an 80% chance of success generates a price target of 375p (from 300p previously).

Dec69 - Skeptic @Penny, I believe you're right in the errors, its what the rest of the business is worth.
BE12:02pm

We incorporate ASDA into our Sainsbury forecasts from 20⁄21: We assume EBITDA synergies of a little over £500m by year two – in line with guidance. just as importantly, we assume that Sainsbury's core EBIT margins drift downwards modestly and that asda’s margins fall by a further 60bps pre-merger. The outcome is very significant accretion…: for the second year post-completion (ie the year to March 2022E), we estimate the combined entity would have EpS of c36p,
.60% accretion compared with standalone Sainsbury (c22p). This is driven partly by synergies and helped by the fact that the deal is c40% debt-funded.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

…even in cautious scenarios: We have explored the EPS outcome when taking more cautious views on the extent of store disposals (sales, profit and proceeds) and the underlying margin movement at Sainsbury and ASDA in the meantime. Even in this cautious scenario we derive 21⁄22E EpS of c29p (.30% accretion). The stock would still be trading at a c25% discount to the Tesco⁄Morrison average for the same year. upside beyond the headline synergies: Our model assumes £500m of net synergies as
per guidance. however, the companies noted that the synergy estimate only includes price harmonization with suppliers (not improvement) and that there is nothing included for non-food.
